item.title: Why Web Accessibility Matters
item.description:
Making the web accessible ensures that everyone regardless of ability can navigate, understand, and interact with digital content.

Why Accessibility Is Essential

Web accessibility allows people with visual, auditory, motor, or cognitive impairments to use websites with equal access. When developers design with accessibility in mind, the web becomes more usable for everyone, not just people with disabilities.

This website highlights and demonstrates several important accessibility principles:

  • Alternative Text
  • Keyboard Navigation
  • Light & Dark Modes
  • Resizable Text
  • Color Contrast
  • Screen Readers

To explore these examples in depth, see the extended guide in the next article.

item.title: Essential Web Accessibility Examples and Why They Matter
item.description:
Accessibility improves digital experiences by ensuring that websites can be used by people with a wide range of disabilities including visual, auditory, cognitive, and motor impairments. Below are several key accessibility features, why they matter, and how they support inclusive design.

Alternative Text

Alternative text (alt text) provides written descriptions for images so users who rely on screen readers can understand visual content.
It is also important when an image fails to load or when users browse with assistive tools.
